Detailed Description

CSGObject represents a primitive when divided into triangles.

CSGObject is an object formed from triangles. Every primitive is actually a friendly interface to a CSGObject

Member Function Documentation

void CSGObject::Clip (  CSGObject *  obj,
CSGObject *  clip,
bool  internal,
CSGObject *  result
)  [static]
 

Clips out part of an object, which is either inside or outside another object based on the "internal" flag.

Parameters:
obj Object to be clipped
clip Object to be clipped against
internal If internal is true, the part of obj inside clip is returned, else outside part is returned.
result Resulting triangles from the clipping are added into result object

BoundBox* CSGObject::GetBoundBox (   )  [inline]
 

Returns the bounding volume of this object. This function does not calculate the bounds, User of the CSGObject class has to set the bounds manually

void CSGObject::Render (   ) 
 

This is the actual part wherein all the triangles are rendered

Sets the bounding volume

BoundBox

Member Data Documentation

BoundBox* CSGObject::bounds
 

Bounding volume of this object

CSGPoint* CSGObject::points
 

All the points forming the triangles are stored in this field, so that when two triangles are sharing same vertex, memory is not wasted. This is also useful in clipping, where in each point of an object is checked whether it is inside or outside of another object bounding volume

std::vector<CSGTriangle*> CSGObject::triangles
 

Triangles are stored in a vector.

See also:
